pullRequest.body:
This PR fills in a todo in `Combinatorics/Colex` by providing the natural order isomorphism between `Nat` and `Colex Nat` that maps each `n` to the set of indices of ones in the binary expansion of `n`. 

We define `bitIndices n` to be the sorted list of indices of 1's in the binary expansion of `n`, and prove a few API lemmas for it. We then provide the corresponding bijection between `Nat` and `Finset Nat`. 

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

nodes.body:
> > The definition `bitSet` could be argued to fit in `Nat/Bits` or `Nat/Digits`, but both are quite far back in the import hierarchy compared to `Finset`, and the proof of bijectivity uses the machinery in `Colex`.
> 
> According to #11757, they shouldn't be, so I believe you could put that material there, or at least in a separate file since it really sticks out from the rest of `Combinatorics.Colex`.

You're right that it sticks out. I've moved it to a separate file - importing `Colex` in `Nat.Bits` causes circular dependencies, and unwinding them before #11757 is likely wasted effort.
Coming here from PR triage: is this PR still blocked on a zulip decision?

> The definition `bitSet` could be argued to fit in `Nat/Bits` or `Nat/Digits`, but both are quite far back in the import hierarchy compared to `Finset`, and the proof of bijectivity uses the machinery in `Colex`. 

According to #11757, they shouldn't be, so I believe you could put that material there, or at least in a separate file since it really sticks out from the rest of `Combinatorics.Colex`.

No, I didn't pay attention but https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/12346/commits/69c62a139d10d93eca3326e28b17dc553b44c20b changed the PR to follow the convention explained in https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/144837-PR-reviews/topic/.2312346.20Colexicographic.20order.20on.20.60Finset.20Nat.60.

Thanks :tada:

Please don't indent the inside of docstrings

```suggestion
def Nat.bitsFinset (n : ℕ) : Finset ℕ := by
```
is more accurate maybe?
Possibly, but it isn't so nice-looking mathematically, and I think there is little danger of ambiguity. I'll let others weigh in.
Awaiting opinions on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/144837-PR-reviews/topic/.2312346.20Colexicographic.20order.20on.20.60Finset.20Nat.60

```suggestion

This could also be defined using `bits`, but it seems easier to avoid the `List` api. -/
```
Can you use `map` here instead? It will be faster and have nicer defeqs. Same for cons instead of insert below.
edit : never mind
Should this be a (sorted) list instead of a finset? Nothing about the name suggests that it should be a finset. See Nat.factors for a similar case of using a list instead.
In the context of colex, it should be a finset. But that doesn't mean we can't construct it as a list originally.
I think `Combinatorics.Colex` should import `Data.Nat.BitIndices`, not the other way around. Can you turn the imports around?

The rest of the file uses
```suggestion
theorem lt_geomSum_of_mem {a : ℕ} (hn : 2 ≤ n) (hi : a ∈ s) : a < ∑ i in s, n ^ i :=
```

```suggestion
@[simp] theorem toFinset_bitIndices_twoPowSum (s : Finset ℕ) :
```

```suggestion
@[simp] theorem twoPowSum_toFinset_bitIndices (n : ℕ) :
```
Please explain that new `twoPowSum`naming convention next to the explanation for `geomSum`
where exactly do you mean?
Module doc of `Algebra.GeomSum`

I don't see anywhere that this fits. The (obvious) convention of using  one of `geom_sum` or `geomSum` to denote geometric sum isn't really explicitly documented in that file, and adding a description of `twoPowSum` would look strange given that it isn't referenced anywhere in that file.
I could see this making sense in a separate PR which does some tidying up, including picking one of `geom_sum` or `geomSum` to use everywhere.
Yeah sure

```suggestion
/-- The equivalence between `ℕ` and `Finset ℕ` that maps `∑ i in s, 2^i` to `s`. -/
```

```suggestion
## TODO

Relate the material in this file to `Nat.digits` and `Nat.bits`.
```
Please keep imports sorted if possible
Can you point to a reference that this is the preferred style? It seems to me like either this should be in the style guide and enforced by a linter (as in `mathlib.lean`) or up to the author.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(Combinatorics/Colex): binary expansions give the colexicographic order on `Finset Nat`

nodes.body:
> The definition `bitSet` could be argued to fit in `Nat/Bits` or `Nat/Digits`, but both are quite far back in the import hierarchy compared to `Finset`, and the proof of bijectivity uses the machinery in `Colex`. 

According to #11757, they shouldn't be, so I believe you could put that material there, or at least in a separate file since it really sticks out from the rest of `Combinatorics.Colex`.

> > The definition `bitSet` could be argued to fit in `Nat/Bits` or `Nat/Digits`, but both are quite far back in the import hierarchy compared to `Finset`, and the proof of bijectivity uses the machinery in `Colex`.
> 
> According to #11757, they shouldn't be, so I believe you could put that material there, or at least in a separate file since it really sticks out from the rest of `Combinatorics.Colex`.

You're right that it sticks out. I've moved it to a separate file - importing `Colex` in `Nat.Bits` causes circular dependencies, and unwinding them before #11757 is likely wasted effort.
Coming here from PR triage: is this PR still blocked on a zulip decision?

No, I didn't pay attention but https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/12346/commits/69c62a139d10d93eca3326e28b17dc553b44c20b changed the PR to follow the convention explained in https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/144837-PR-reviews/topic/.2312346.20Colexicographic.20order.20on.20.60Finset.20Nat.60.
